By Mrs Hale, Of .New Port, .Ne.u Hampshire.
My boy, thou wilt dream the world is fair,
And thy spirit will sigh TO roam,
Aud thou mast go; but never when there,
Forget the light of home.
Tho peasore may smile with ray more bright,
1t dax1es to lead astray;
Like the meteors fash twill deepen the night,
When thou treadest the lonely way
But the hearth of home has constant fame,
And pure vestal fire;
Twill burn, twill burn. forever the same,
For nature feeds the pyre.
The sea of ambition is tempest tos,


And thy iopes may vanish like foam;
But when sails are siivered and rudder lost,
Then look TO the light Of home.
And thcre like star through the midnight cloud.
Thou shalt SEE the beacon bright
For never, till shining on thy shroud,


Can be qneach'd its holy light.
The sun of fame, aye twill gild the name,


But the heart ne'er felt its ray;
And fashions smiles that rich ones claim,


Are but beams of wintry day.
And how cold and dim those beams would be-
Should fe's wretched wanderer come.
But my boy, when the world is dark to thee,


Then turn to the light of home. CoRNELii
rHE LIGHT OF HOMIE.

The Tartan arrows fell like rain,
They clank'd on helm, OH mail, on chain;
In blood, in hate, in death, we're tWined
Savage and Greek, mad, bleeding, blnd
And still on flank, on front, and rear,
Ragged, Constantine, thy thirstiest spear
Brassy and pale, a type Of doom,


Laboured the moon, through deepening gloom .
Down plunged her orb--hWas pitchy night
Now Turkman, turn thy relns for fight
On rush'd their thousands through the dark
But in their camp ruddy spark,
Like an uncertain meteor, reePd
Thy hand, brave king, that frebrand wheeld
Wild burst the burning element


O'er man and courser, flag and tent
And through the blaze the Greeks outsprang,
Like tigers, bloody, foot and fang,


With daggers' stab and falchion's sweep
Deying the stunnd and staggering heap
Till lay the slave by chief and Khan,
And all was gore that once was man.
There's wailing on the Euxine shore
Her Ghivalry shall ride no more.


There's wailing on thy hills, Altai,


For chiefs-the Grecian vutures' prey.
But Bosphorus, thy silver wave


Hears shouts for the returning brave.
The kingliest Of her kingly line,
For there comes glorious Constantnes

BY THE nEv. cRoLY.
night attack by Constantine Paleoogus, on detsche
camp of the troops of Mahomet the second at the sieg
of Copstantnope.


THe Turkman lay beside the river,
The wind payd loose through bow and quyer.
The charger on the bank fed free,
The shield hung glittering from the tree,
The trumpet, shawn, and a,abal.
Were hid from dew bv cloak and pail;
For long and weary was the way
The hordes had marched that burning day
Above them, on the sky Of June,
Broad as a buckler. glow ID the moon,
Flooding with glory vale and hill,
In silver sprang the mountain ril',
The weeping shrub in silver bents
A pile Of silver stood the tent;
All soundIess, sweet tranquility,
All beauty, HILL and tent, and tree.
There came sound-'twas like the gusii
When night winds shake the roses bush.
There came sound--twas like the flow
OF rivers swelpd with melting snow;
There came a sonnd-iwas ike the tread
OF wolves along the valleys bed,
There came sound--tNas like the roar
OF ocean on its winter shore


ssDeath to the Turk /" uprose the yell;
On roll'd the chargc-a thunder peal
THE GREEK AND TEE TuRIxnnAN.

BY MRS. HEaANs.
Rocks Of my country let the cloud
Your crested heights array;
And rise ye like fortress proud,
Above the surge and spray
My spirit Rreets you as ye stand.
Breasting the bi'low's f,am
Oh, thus for ever guard the iands
The seyei'd land Of houe!
| have left sunny skies behind
Lighting up classic -hrnes,
Ard music in the southern wind,
And sunshine on the vines.
The breathings Of the myrtle flowers
Have foated DER my wsy.
Ihe pilgrims voice at vesper hours
Hath sootli'd me with its lay.
The isles of Greece, the hills of Spain,
The purple heavens of Rome
Yes, all are glorious yet again
bless thee. land vt home
For thine the Sabbath peace, my land.
And hine the guarded hearth;
And thine the dead, the noble band
That make thee holy earth.
Their voices meet me in thy breeze.
Their steps are on thy plains;
Their names, by old majestic trees.
Are whispered round thy fanes:
Their blood hath mingled with the tide
OF thine exulting sea -
oh, be i, still JOY, pride.


To live and die for thee!

full articles.headline: rHE LIGHT OF HOMIE.
full articles.article:
By Mrs Hale, Of .New Port, .Ne.u Hampshire.
My boy, thou wilt dream the world is fair,
And thy spirit will sigh TO roam,
Aud thou mast go; but never when there,
Forget the light of home.
Tho peasore may smile with ray more bright,
1t dax1es to lead astray;
Like the meteors fash twill deepen the night,
When thou treadest the lonely way
But the hearth of home has constant fame,
And pure vestal fire;
Twill burn, twill burn. forever the same,
For nature feeds the pyre.
The sea of ambition is tempest tos,


And thy iopes may vanish like foam;
But when sails are siivered and rudder lost,
Then look TO the light Of home.
And thcre like star through the midnight cloud.
Thou shalt SEE the beacon bright
For never, till shining on thy shroud,


Can be qneach'd its holy light.
The sun of fame, aye twill gild the name,


But the heart ne'er felt its ray;
And fashions smiles that rich ones claim,


Are but beams of wintry day.
And how cold and dim those beams would be-
Should fe's wretched wanderer come.
But my boy, when the world is dark to thee,


Then turn to the light of home. CoRNELii

The Tartan arrows fell like rain,
They clank'd on helm, OH mail, on chain;
In blood, in hate, in death, we're tWined
Savage and Greek, mad, bleeding, blnd
And still on flank, on front, and rear,
Ragged, Constantine, thy thirstiest spear
Brassy and pale, a type Of doom,


Laboured the moon, through deepening gloom .
Down plunged her orb--hWas pitchy night
Now Turkman, turn thy relns for fight
On rush'd their thousands through the dark
But in their camp ruddy spark,
Like an uncertain meteor, reePd
Thy hand, brave king, that frebrand wheeld
Wild burst the burning element


O'er man and courser, flag and tent
And through the blaze the Greeks outsprang,
Like tigers, bloody, foot and fang,


With daggers' stab and falchion's sweep
Deying the stunnd and staggering heap
Till lay the slave by chief and Khan,
And all was gore that once was man.
There's wailing on the Euxine shore
Her Ghivalry shall ride no more.


There's wailing on thy hills, Altai,


For chiefs-the Grecian vutures' prey.
But Bosphorus, thy silver wave


Hears shouts for the returning brave.
The kingliest Of her kingly line,
For there comes glorious Constantnes

full articles.headline: THE GREEK AND TEE TuRIxnnAN.
full articles.article:
BY THE nEv. cRoLY.
night attack by Constantine Paleoogus, on detsche
camp of the troops of Mahomet the second at the sieg
of Copstantnope.


THe Turkman lay beside the river,
The wind payd loose through bow and quyer.
The charger on the bank fed free,
The shield hung glittering from the tree,
The trumpet, shawn, and a,abal.
Were hid from dew bv cloak and pail;
For long and weary was the way
The hordes had marched that burning day
Above them, on the sky Of June,
Broad as a buckler. glow ID the moon,
Flooding with glory vale and hill,
In silver sprang the mountain ril',
The weeping shrub in silver bents
A pile Of silver stood the tent;
All soundIess, sweet tranquility,
All beauty, HILL and tent, and tree.
There came sound-'twas like the gusii
When night winds shake the roses bush.
There came sound--twas like the flow
OF rivers swelpd with melting snow;
There came a sonnd-iwas ike the tread
OF wolves along the valleys bed,
There came sound--tNas like the roar
OF ocean on its winter shore


ssDeath to the Turk /" uprose the yell;
On roll'd the chargc-a thunder peal

full articles.headline:
From The .Nlseum Of Foreign Literature and Science


THE CLIFFS OF DOVER.
full articles.article:
BY MRS. HEaANs.
Rocks Of my country let the cloud
Your crested heights array;
And rise ye like fortress proud,
Above the surge and spray
My spirit Rreets you as ye stand.
Breasting the bi'low's f,am
Oh, thus for ever guard the iands
The seyei'd land Of houe!
| have left sunny skies behind
Lighting up classic -hrnes,
Ard music in the southern wind,
And sunshine on the vines.
The breathings Of the myrtle flowers
Have foated DER my wsy.
Ihe pilgrims voice at vesper hours
Hath sootli'd me with its lay.
The isles of Greece, the hills of Spain,
The purple heavens of Rome
Yes, all are glorious yet again
bless thee. land vt home
For thine the Sabbath peace, my land.
And hine the guarded hearth;
And thine the dead, the noble band
That make thee holy earth.
Their voices meet me in thy breeze.
Their steps are on thy plains;
Their names, by old majestic trees.
Are whispered round thy fanes:
Their blood hath mingled with the tide
OF thine exulting sea -
oh, be i, still JOY, pride.


To live and die for thee!

full articles.headline: COMMENT ON THE LAWS OF ENGLAND
full articles.article:
Extracted from The writings Of Mr. JoLa Wesey


"In the beginning of July, ,76l, was desired 10
call poor prisoner in the castle Of York, (Eng-
land. III had formerly occasion to take nnlite ol
bidsous monster, called Chancery bill now
saw the fellow 10 il called a Declaration The
plain fac, was this Some time since, man who
lived near YARN, Sssist-d others in running some
brandy his share was worth nearly tout pounds.
After he had wholly left off that work. and wss fol
lowing his own business, tina, Of weever. he was
arrested and sent to York gaol And not long
al er came down Declarations that Jack had Ian
ded vessel ladened with brandy and Geneva,
whereby he was indebed to his Sovereign Lord the
King, in The sum of 576l. and upwards And TO
tell this Worthy story the lawyer takes up | 3 OF IA
sheets OF the triple sbampi paper.


30 England. Will this reproach never be rolled
away from thee Is there any thing like this to be
found, either among Turks o, heathens In the
name oil Justice, mercy. and common sense, ask,
1st.--Why do men lie for lying sake Is It only
10 keep their hands in? What need else OF saying
i, was the por, of London When every knew
the Brandy was slandeo 500 miles from thence.
| "Whst a monstrous contempt oil truth does this
show, or rather hatred to it 2d.-Where is the
Justice OF swelling Al, into 576l.e Sd.-Where is
the common sense Of taking up IA sheets Of paper
10 tell story, that may be told in ten nes9 4th.-
Where is the mercy OF thus grinding the lace Of
the poor beggared prisoner? Would not this
be execrabe vlllany. if the paper and writing to
gether, were only Cd sheet, when they had stript
him already OF his little all, and had not left him IA
groats ln the worlds


cit is certain that nothing can be said in de
fence of our law proceedings. They are often alb
surd highly oppressive TO the subject, and disgrace
| full to civilized nation In criminal cases, how
often does the indictment magnify and exsggsrstr
both the crime and every circumstance connected
with it, beyond all the bounds OF truth and proba
bilty? Hence it becomes extremely difficult fol-
the Jurymen to discharge their duty with good
conscience. And we seldom punishnents duly
We say in other cases where the tauology and cir
cumlocution peculiar to the language Of our law
the delay of Judgment in the courts. and the ter
giversation permitted through the whole proceed
ings render it impossible for honest man il
middling life to obtain his right against villain
without the utmost danger OF being ruined! A
man who robs ON the highway ia hung-but vii
lain who robs by means Of the chicanery, delay ant
expsnse Of the law, escapes with impunty, and i
applauded."


The March Of Intellect An irriia,ed school
master not being able 10 make clowniSh schois
remember the word Mule exclaimed while riding
out one day, Now, you BOBBY don't you know
what's between horse and ass 2 Why yes sir
to be sure do-ev'ry fool knows that how somever
Then why don't you tell me?-say directly wha
it is between the horse and the ass or III punisl
you,'' Why the saddle, to be sure. sir y knowe
